Now let's look closely at one controversial issue likely to be affected by Justice Scalia's death.
That is abortion.
Since 2011, Republican-controlled statehouses have passed dozens of state laws restricting abortions.
Those laws have been winding their way up through appeals courts, and now the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments in a major abortion case in just two weeks.
NPR's Jennifer Ludden reports.
This is the biggest abortion case before the high court in at least a decade.
A Texas law requires that doctors have local admitting privileges and that clinics make costly building upgrades to operate like outpatient surgical centers.
These are laws numerous other states have also passed.
Justice Scalia was widely expected to provide a fifth vote to uphold these restrictions.
Now, without him it may not change much for Texas.
A four-four split in the court would leave in place a lower court ruling that upheld these provisions.
Ilyse Hogue of NARAL Pro-Choice America says that would shut down clinics that perform abortion.
She points out some clinics have already closed because of other parts of the Texas law.
We would be looking at an even greater health care crisis in Texas than we're already facing.
But a split decision in the Supreme Court would have no national precedent.
That means other appeals court rulings striking down similar laws would also stand, and Hogue says there are more cases to come.
I think this vacancy is far, far greater in terms of its implication than this one case in Texas.
There are so many laws looking to restrict not only abortion access and abortion rights but a broader set of reproductive rights in front of the court right now.
One of them also comes out next month.
The court hears a challenge to the Affordable Care Act's mandate on covering birth control for female employees.
Abortion opponents are mourning the loss of a great ally in Justice Scalia.
Clarke Forsythe is senior counsel with Americans United for Life.
He was one of the two justices on the court who has publicly opposed Roe versus Wade in prior cases in prior votes, and he was probably the most vocal and long-standing having been there since 1986.
